body.p: The suggested algorithm presented by Dr Ruben1 on the way our physician brains should be evaluating patients with otitis media is concise and insightful. This evaluative process is applicable to both infectious otitis media (OM) and otitis media with effusion (OME). Although OME is now understood to be an allergic disease,2,3 the author omits “allergy” in his list of intrinsic susceptibility factors (Table 1). Given that more than 20% of the general population is atopic, that up to 90% of patients with chronic OME have been shown to be atopic by objective testing, and that chronic OME resolves with immunotherapy4 (as published in the journal of which the author is editor-in-chief), this seems to be a significant exclusion. Allergy is a much more prevalent risk factor than all the intrinsic factors listed in his Table 1 combined. It is also more easily treated than are genetic syndromal abnormalities, maxillofacial malformations, abnormal mucociliary physiology, or immune deficiencies.

In consideration of “extrinsic susceptibility factors,” the presence of common allergens (dust, pollen, pets, molds) to which the patient is sensitive has been shown to be a multiplier of several of the factors listed. Atopy more than doubles the risk of OME among children exposed to tobacco smoke or in day care and quadruples the risk of an acute otitis developing into OME.5 The exponential increase of allergies these past 2 decades possibly is as much responsible for what the author identifies as the “substantial increase in the subsequent incidence and prevalence of otitis media with effusion” as is the use of antibiotics. It would therefore be helpful if allergy were included in the checklist of intrinsic factors and the presence of allergens in the environment be included among extrinsic factors cofactored into an otolaryngologist’s decision making.
